page.title: 01Moors E of Over Silton
page.content: Most of this National Park land is a heather-covered plateau of moor, stretching diagonally from NW to SE. This plateau, varying in width from a half to one kilometre, reaches to 400m in two places, & drops steeply below 370m. These moors are deserted apart from hikers, & shooting parties searching for grouse & partridge. There are very steep ravines in the SW of the block, where little can grow apart from heather and bracken. Mixed farming is carried out in the E & NE, where the landscape is greener & more gentle, & conifer plantations & old deciduous woods are found. The rough grazing up the hillsides is most suitable for sheep- farming, while some cereal growing & dairy farming can be seen lower down the valley. The road from Osmotherley to Hawnby is in the NE of the block.
